ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I have learned to think more critically about writing across different forms of media and integrating various sources, which will be helpful in my future courses. I have also learned to better analyze text that isn't necessarily as designed for close reading.
Engaging in collective criticism
This course developed my understanding of the way that literature can be catered to children and young adults and the variety of topics that can be introduced to young people via this medium.

This class was such a bright light in a tough semester. Reading young adult fiction was a lovely way take a break from the virtual world and read a fast paced books. I really enjoyed the reading responses Prof. Richard assigned, as it gave us opportunities to do lots of different types of writing.
Learning about young adult literature as a genre while also learning about tropes spanning literature as a whole and study of the uniqueness of the young adult

This class taught me about new ways to critique novels as well as how to enjoy books more. Being a YA fiction class, I had to think a lot more about the audience than in other English classes and less about the nuance in style, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: I loved the creativity involved in the collective criticisms and one of the options for the final paper. Many of the books were also incredible. I enjoyed all of them!
Great books and creative approaches to critical analysis each week. Also great groupwork
The format and workload of this course was clearly laid out and manageable of this challenging semester.
Great readings, great discussions, and a great prof. No improvements

This class was amazing! Professor Richards did everything she could to ensure a seamless transition into online learning. Beyond that, all of the readings are incredible and fun. I stayed up many nights because I didnt want to put the book down, and it rarely felt like assigned reading. Our discussions were very open-ended and everyone participated. I loved this class!

Great syllabus and discussion format - professor used break out sessions and had discussion prompts each week which helped facilitate conversation; great supplementary readings that related the fantastical worlds of the novels to the real world and its current issues

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The modified weekly assignments were  nice
This class didn't seem much different than it would have been in person. The discussion sections sometimes got awkward because we did so many of them.

Professor Richards was amazing and putting us in breakout groups, making sure everyone spoke, and letting everyone in the class feel comfortable. We got even closer with our semi weekly discussion posts. I especially liked that she let us use the chat to write our thoughts as well, so it felt less awkward.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would! You read some amazing books and Professor Richards is awesome. The collective criticisms are actually fun, and I also enjoyed writing my final paper!
ABSOLUTELY!! Fun books and great professor
I would absolutely recommend this course to any student, especially if it is still being taught by Jill Richards.
Yes! Prof. Richards is great and reading young adult fiction was so much fun.
Yes

Yes! If you are not an English major, you will feel like youre learning so much just by being around people who talk about books all the time. Its also the kind of class where you want to do well because you can tell how much the professor cares. It was amazing!

Yes, this class was so fun and a nice switch up from reading heavily academic readings that usually come along with English courses. The professor was great and really had fun with the materials and encouraged us to do the same
